fields.Study Name: Is drug-induced sleep endoscopy associated with better outcomes after soft tissue surgery for sleep apnea? A systematic review and meta-analysis
fields.Key Findings: DISE was not associated with a higher success rate or significant changes in AHI, minimal SpO2, or ESS compared to no DISE. The authors conclude that soft tissue surgery does not yield better results after DISE, but the evidence level is low.
fields.Citation: Lisan Q, Baudouin R, Lechien JR, Hans S, Blumen M. Is drug-induced sleep endoscopy associated with better outcomes after soft tissue surgery for sleep apnea? A systematic review and meta-analysis. Clin Otolaryngol. 2023 Mar;48(2):122-129.

fields.Study Name: Maxillomandibular Advancement and Upper Airway Stimulation for Treatment of Obstructive Sleep Apnea: A Systematic Review
fields.AHI Reduction %: MMA: from 54.6 to 10.1; UAS: from 35.2 to 15.0
fields.ESS Improvement: MMA: from 13.1 to 6.7; UAS: from 11.4 to 7.0
fields.ODI Improvement: MMA: from 35.1 to 6.3; UAS: from 26.5 to 14.6
fields.Quality of Life Score: MMA: FOSQ improvement, SF-36 no improvement; UAS: FOSQ improvement
fields.Complication Rate: MMA: 0-18% major complications; UAS: 0-7% serious device-related events
fields.Revision Rate: MMA: Reoperation for hardware removal and non-union; UAS: Repositioning/replacement of device components
fields.Key Findings: Both MMA and UAS are effective and generally safe therapies for OSA. However, due to the limitations of the included studies, there is no evidence yet to directly compare these two procedures in OSA treatment.
fields.Citation: Zhou N, Ho J-PTF, Spijker R, Aarab G, de Vries N, Ravesloot MJL, de Lange J. Maxillomandibular Advancement and Upper Airway Stimulation for Treatment of Obstructive Sleep Apnea: A Systematic Review. J Clin Med. 2022 Nov 15;11(22):6782.

fields.Study Name: Objective and subjective long term outcome of maxillomandibular advancement in obstructive sleep apnea
fields.Quality of Life Score: Significant improvement in PSQI and ISI total scores.
fields.Key Findings: MMA is a clinically effective treatment for patients with moderate-to-severe OSA as demonstrated by significant long-term decrease in AHI and improvement in neurocognitive testing.
fields.Citation: Lin, C. H., Chin, W. C., Huang, Y. S., Wang, P. F., Li, K. K., Pirelli, P., ... & Guilleminault, C. (2020). Objective and subjective long term outcome of maxillomandibular advancement in obstructive sleep apnea. Sleep medicine, 74, 289-296.

fields.Study Name: Results of the ADHERE upper airway stimulation registry and predictors of therapy efficacy
fields.Key Findings: Across a multi-institutional study, UAS therapy continues to show significant improvement in subjective and objective OSA outcomes. This analysis shows that the therapy effect is durable and adherence is high. In a multivariate model, only female sex and lower baseline body mass index remained as significant predictors of therapy response.
fields.Citation: Thaler E, Schwab R, Maurer J, et al. Results of the ADHERE upper airway stimulation registry and predictors of therapy efficacy. Laryngoscope. 2020;130(5):1333-1338.

fields.Study Name: Surgical versus Non-Surgical Management of Obstructive Sleep-disordered Breathing in Children: A Meta-analysis
fields.Quality of Life Score: Significant improvement in disease-specific quality of life (OSA-18 and CAS-15 scores) in the surgical group compared to the non-surgical group (p < 0.001).
fields.Complication Rate: No statistically significant difference in adverse events between surgical and non-surgical groups (p=0.713). Post-operative bleeding may occur in up to 5% of children.
fields.Key Findings: Surgical intervention (adenotonsillectomy) provides a significant clinical improvement in disease-specific quality of life and reduces healthcare utilization for children with obstructive sleep-disordered breathing compared to non-surgical management.
fields.Citation: Abd El Hamid AA, Askoura AM, Abdel Hamed DM, Taha MS, Allam MF. Surgical versus Non-Surgical Management of Obstructive Sleep-disordered Breathing in Children: A Meta-analysis. Open Respir Med J. 2020;14:47-52.

fields.Study Name: Effectiveness of Palatopharyngeal Surgery Modifications in Obstructive Sleep Apnea: A Meta-analysis
fields.Key Findings: Palatopharyngeal surgery without tonsillectomy is effective, but results differ significantly regarding surgical techniques. Powered instruments, sutures, and muscle relocation techniques have been reported to yield more favorable results compared to cold steel, radiofrequency, laser, and palatal implants.
fields.Citation: Tschopp S, Meinert F, Mantokoudis G, Caversaccio M, Borner U. Effectiveness of Palatopharyngeal Surgery Modifications in Obstructive Sleep Apnea: A Meta-analysis. OTO Open. 2025 Jun 19;9(2):e70144.

fields.Study Name: The Effectiveness of Tonsillectomy and Adenoidectomy in the Treatment of Pediatric Obstructive Sleep Apnea/Hypopnea Syndrome: A Meta-Analysis
fields.Key Findings: T/A is effective in the treatment of OSAHS. However, success rates are far below 100%, which could have far-reaching pediatric public health consequences.
fields.Citation: Brietzke SE, Gallagher D. The effectiveness of tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy in the treatment of pediatric obstructive sleep apnea/hypopnea syndrome: a meta-analysis. Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg. 2006 Jun;134(6):979-84.

fields.Study Name: Hypoglossal nerve stimulation versus positive airway pressure therapy for obstructive sleep apnea
fields.Procedure: Hypoglossal nerve stimulation (HNS) vs. Positive Airway Pressure (PAP)
fields.ESS Improvement: HNS: 8.0 ± 5.1 points reduction, PAP: 3.9 ± 6.8 points reduction
fields.Quality of Life Score: ESS improvement reported, no other scores mentioned.
fields.Key Findings: Patients treated with HNS therapy had significantly greater improvements in daytime sleepiness compared to PAP therapy, while the mean reduction of AHI and overall effectiveness were comparable for both treatments.
fields.Citation: Heiser C, Steffen A, Strollo PJ Jr, Giaie-Miniet C, Vanderveken OM, Hofauer B. Hypoglossal nerve stimulation versus positive airway pressure therapy for obstructive sleep apnea. Sleep Breath. 2023 May;27(2):693-701.

fields.Study Name: Bariatric surgery and obstructive sleep apnea: a systematic review and meta-analysis
fields.Key Findings: Bariatric surgeries are effective in reducing obesity among patients with OSA in addition to OSA severity measures. However, the low rate of OSA remission suggests that the main etiology of OSA is not only obesity but also includes other important variables such as the anatomy of the jaw.
fields.Citation: Al Oweidat K, Toubasi AA, Abu Tawileh RB, Abu Tawileh HB, Hasuneh MM. Bariatric surgery and obstructive sleep apnea: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Sleep Breath. 2023;27(6):2283-2294.

fields.Study Name: STAR Trial: Stimulation Therapy for Apnea Reduction
fields.Procedure: Inspire Upper Airway Stimulation (UAS) - Hypoglossal Nerve Stimulation
fields.ESS Improvement: Normalization of scores increased from 33% to 78%
fields.Quality of Life Score: Normalization of FOSQ scores increased from 15% to 67%
fields.Revision Rate: 6% serious device-related events requiring lead/device adjustments
fields.Key Findings: Upper-airway stimulation led to significant and sustained improvements in objective and subjective measurements of the severity of obstructive sleep apnea over 5 years. Adverse events were uncommon, and the therapy was found to be a successful and appropriate long-term treatment for individuals with moderate to severe OSA.
fields.Citation: Strollo, P. J., Jr, Soose, R. J., Maurer, J. T., de Vries, N., Cornelius, J., Froymovich, O., Hanson, R. D., Padhya, T. A., Steward, D. L., Gillespie, M. B., Woodson, B. T., Van de Heyning, P. H., Goetting, M. G., Vanderveken, O. M., Feldman, N., Knaack, L., & Strohl, K. P. (2014). Upper-airway stimulation for obstructive sleep apnea. New England Journal of Medicine, 370(2), 139-149.

fields.Study Name: Transoral robotic base of tongue reduction for obstructive sleep apnea: a systematic review and meta-analysis
fields.Procedure: Transoral robotic surgery (TORS) base of tongue (BOT) reduction
fields.ODI Improvement: 5.1% absolute increase in lowest oxygen saturation
fields.Quality of Life Score: Snoring visual analog scale reduction from 9.3 to 2.4
fields.Key Findings: TORS BOT reduction decreases AHI and symptoms of sleepiness in adult patients with OSA. It is considered successful in a majority of cases; however, further studies must be performed to optimize patient selection criteria to achieve higher rates of success.
fields.Citation: Miller SC, Nguyen SA, Ong AA, Gillespie MB. Transoral robotic base of tongue reduction for obstructive sleep apnea: A systematic review and meta-analysis. Laryngoscope. 2017;127(1):258-265.

fields.Study Name: Reviewing the Systematic Reviews in OSA Surgery
fields.Key Findings: Although obstructive sleep apnea surgery is associated with improved outcomes in most studies, the level and quality of evidence reviews requires improvement. Outcomes for sleepiness and snoring demonstrated significant improvement across included reviews.
fields.Citation: Certal, V., Nishino, N., Camacho, M., & Capasso, R. (2013). Reviewing the systematic reviews in OSA surgery. Otolaryngology--head and neck surgery : official journal of American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery, 149(6), 817–829.

fields.Study Name: Upper Airway Stimulation for Obstructive Sleep Apnea: 5-Year Outcomes
fields.Quality of Life Score: Normalization of FOSQ scores from 15% to 67%
fields.Key Findings: Improvements in sleepiness, quality of life, and respiratory outcomes are observed with 5 years of UAS. Serious adverse events are uncommon. UAS is a nonanatomic surgical treatment with long-term benefit for individuals with moderate to severe OSA who have failed nasal continuous positive airway pressure.
fields.Citation: Woodson BT, Strohl KP, Soose RJ, et al. Upper Airway Stimulation for Obstructive Sleep Apnea: 5-Year Outcomes. Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg. 2018;159(1):194-202.

fields.Study Name: Systematic review and updated meta-analysis of multi-level surgery for patients with OSA
fields.ODI Improvement: Significant improvement in lowest saturation of oxygen (%)
fields.Key Findings: Multilevel surgery for OSA patients is associated with significant improvement of treatment outcomes.
fields.Citation: Su YY, Lin PW, Lin HC, et al. Systematic review and updated meta-analysis of multi-level surgery for patients with OSA. Auris Nasus Larynx. 2022;49(3):421-430. doi:10.1016/j.anl.2021.10.001

fields.Study Name: The Role of Isolated Nasal Surgery in Obstructive Sleep Apnea Therapy-A Systematic Review
fields.AHI Reduction %: An overall decrease of 4.08 in the mean difference between preoperative and postoperative AHI was found, but the percentage is not specified.
fields.ESS Improvement: The ESS was significantly lower after nasal surgery in eighteen studies.
fields.Quality of Life Score: Nasal surgery in patients with nasal obstruction and OSA improves disease-specific quality of life, snoring and ESS. One of the included studies used the SF-36 to assess quality of life.
fields.Key Findings: Isolated nasal surgery did not significantly improve the AHI in the majority of the studies. The meta-analysis suggests a slight decrease in AHI after nasal surgery, but this reduction is not clinically relevant in terms of treatment success. Isolated nasal surgery can possibly improve OSA subjectively (ESS). Isolated nasal surgery should therefore not be recommended as a first-line treatment for OSA.
fields.Citation: Schoustra E, van Maanen P, den Haan C, Ravesloot MJL, de Vries N. The Role of Isolated Nasal Surgery in Obstructive Sleep Apnea Therapy-A Systematic Review. Brain Sci. 2022 Oct 26;12(11):1446.
